document.masterDocTitle: The species of the Chthonius heterodactylus group (Arachnida, Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae) from the eastern Alps and the Carpathians

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The species of the Chthonius heterodactylus group (Arachnida, Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae) from the eastern Alps and the Carpathians

bibRefCitation.author: Hadzi
bibRefCitation.refString: Hadzi, J. (1930) Prilog poznavanju pecinskih pseudoskorpija. Glas Srpske Kraljevske Akademija, Beograd, 67, 115 - 148.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Chthonius cavernarum
(not
Ellingsen 1909
):
Beier 1928
: 313
(misidentification);
Beier 1931
: 91
(misidentification);
Beier 1932
: 53
, fig. 61 (misidentification, in part: see
C. cavernarum
).

Chthonius (C.) raridentatus
Hadži 1930
: 134
, figs 10 –11, 12a–d, 13 a–e;
Beier 1939 b
: 15
, fig. 11 .

Chthonius (C.) ellingseni
Beier 1939 b
: 16
( n. syn. ).

Chthonius (C.) brandmayri
Callaini 1986
: 237
, figs 2 a–e. ( n. syn .).

Chthonius (Chthonius) jalzici
Ćurčić 1988
: 17
, figs 2–8 ( n. syn. ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality
: Slovenia , Kočevsko, Kočevje, Borovec pri Kočevski Reki, Babja luknja pri Borovcu no. 93 (= Frauenloch; Jama pri Borovcu) ( 45 ° 33 ′07″
N 14 ° 47 ′
41 ″E).
Distribution. NE Italy , Austria , Slovenia , Croatia .

Diagnosis ( ♂♀ ). An eyed, epigean
Chthonius ( Chthonius )
from the eastern Alps and northern Dinaric region that differs from other species of the
C. heterodactylus
group in the following combination of characters: carapace without epistome, chaetotaxy 4 : 6 : 4 : 2 : 2 ( 18 ), rarely anterior row m 4m and posterior row m 2m ; chaetotaxy tergites I–IV: 4 : 4 : 4 : 4 ; genital opening of males flanked by aligned setae on each side; fixed chelal finger with 15–26 (♂) or 12–21 (♀) teeth with dental canals, usually with intercalary microdenticles, and with a spatulate distal paraxial seta; movable chelal finger usually with 20–28 (♂) or 16–26 (♀) low, broad, reclined teeth, increasingly reduced towards finger base, reaching back almost to sb ; distal half of movable chelal finger rarely with 6–8 triangular reclined teeth that are wider than high; coupled sensilla pc of movable chelal finger usually between trichobothria st and sb ; chela length 0.86–1.51 (♂) or 0.88–1.74 (♀), movable finger length 0.51–0.90 (♂) or 0.54 –1.0 (♀).

Type material of
Chthonius ellingseni
examined.
AUSTRIA — Carinthia: 2 ♀ ( paralectotypes of
Chthonius (C.) ellingseni Beier, 1939
, present designation), “Annenheim am Ossiachersee / Kärnten. 1893 Sturany leg.” “
Chthonius cavernarum Ell.
/ det. Dr. Beier” ( NHMW ).

SLOVENIA— Gorenjska regija: 1 ♀ ( lectotype of
Chthonius (C.) ellingseni
, present designation)
2 ♂
, 4 T ( paralectotypes of
Chthonius (C.) ellingseni
, present designation), “Crna Prst [Mt. Črna prst] Wochein [Bohinj] / 700-800 m / Juli-August 1899 / Penther leg. XXIV” “
Chthonius cavernarum Ell.
/ det. Dr. Beier” ( NHMW ).

Type material of
Chthonius brandmayri
examined.
SLOVENIA— Obalno—Kraška regija:
1 ♂
( holotype of
Chthonius brandmayri
Callaini, 1986
), “F 4 / Istria—M. Taiano (Slavnik) /
1 .IX. 1975
faggeta chiara / leg. Brandmayr” “
Chthonius brandmayri
n. sp. / ♂ holotypus Callaini det.” ( MSNV ); 1 ♀ ( paratype of
Chthonius brandmayri Callaini
), “Istria—M. Taiano (Slavnik) /
22 .X. 1975
terra rossa (F 2 ) / leg. Brandmayr” “
Chthonius brandmayri
n. sp. / ♀ paratypus Callaini det.” ( MSNV ).

Other material examined. CROATIA— Istarska županija:
3 ♂
, 3 ♀, Učka (= Monte Maggiore), 1390 m a.s.l.,
6 .X. 1990
, F. Gasparo leg., meadow on edge of
Fagus sylvatica
wood;
1 ♂
, id., 950 m a.s.l.,
6 .X. 1990
, F. Gasparo leg., pitfall traps. Ličko–senjska županija:
2 ♂
, 1 ♀, Velebit, 4 km southern of Oltari, 1050 m a.s.l.,
13 .VI. 1996
, G. Colombetta leg., pitfall traps in
Fagus sylvatica
wood. Zagrebačka županija:
2 ♂
, 1 ♀, 2 T, 1 D, Zagreb, Medvednica, Gornji Stenjevec, Veternica špilia,
28 .XII. 2003
, R. Ozimec leg. (ROZ);
2 ♂
, 1 ♀, id.,
9 .IX. 2006
, R. Ozimec leg. (ROZ);
4 ♂
, 2 ♀, 5 D, id.,
13 .V. 2007
, Bedek, Bilandžija & Pavlek leg., traps (ROZ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 59–66.
Chthonius
(C.) raridentatus
Hadži, 1930
, males from Slovenia, Most na Soči, near Jama pod Smoganico. 59–60, Anterior margin of carapace of ♂ (small specimen) (59) and ♂ (large specimen) (60). 61–62, Anterolateral portion of carapace of ♂ (small specimen) (61) and ♂ (large specimen) (62). 63–64, Right chelicera of ♂ (small specimen) (63) and ♂ (large specimen) (64). 65–66, Right chela, lateral view, of ♂ (small specimen) (65) and ♂ (large specimen) (66).

FIGURES 67–74.
Chthonius
(C.) raridentatus
Hadži, 1930
, females from Slovenia, Most na Soči, near Jama pod Smoganico. 67–68, Anterior margin of carapace of ♀ (small specimen) (67) and ♀ (large specimen) (68). 69–70, Anterolateral portion of carapace of ♀ (small specimen) (69) and ♀ (large specimen) (70). 71–72, Right chelicera of ♀ (small specimen) (71) and ♀ (large specimen) (72). 73–74, Right chela, lateral view, of ♀ (small specimen) (73) and ♀ (large specimen) (74).

Description of adults ( ♂♀ ) . Integument pigmented, carapace, tergites, chelicerae and pedipalps brown or pale brown ( lectotype and paralectotypes of
C. ellingseni
with integument decoloured); hispid granulation on lateral surfaces of carapace, on cheliceral palm, on base of cheliceral movable finger and on distal surface of pedipalpal hand. Carapace 1.0– 1.1 (rarely 0.9 or 1.2 ) times longer than broad, posteriorly weakly constricted; anterior margin (
Figs 59 –60
, 67–68 , 75–76 , 82 ) without epistome (rarely with weakly prominent epistome), with sharp denticles between median macrosetae; ocular area as in
Figs 61 –62
, 69–70 , 77 ,
83
; anterior eyes with convex lens (diameter 0.040–0.055 mm ), posterior eyes with flat lens or reduced to spots, all eyes with tapeta (usually evident in recently preserved specimens); distance from anterior eyes to anterior margin of carapace 0.030–0.050 mm ; chaetotaxy 4 : 6 : 4 : 2 : 2 ( 18 ), rarely anterior row m 4m (see
Hadži 1930
: 135 ) and posterior row m 2m (♀ from Slovenia , Urhova jama, no. 505 ); length of anteromedian and anterolateral macrosetae respectively 0.13–0.19 and 0.06–0.11 mm , length of median macrosetae of the ocular row 0.16–0.22 mm , length of posterior macrosetae 0.13–0.19 mm . Standard chaetotaxy of tergites
I–X 4
: 4 : 4 : 4 : 4 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 4 ; tergite I rarely with 2 setae (♂ holotype and ♀ paratype of
C. brandmayri
from Mt. Slavnik;
1 ♂
from Most na Soči, near Jama pod Smoganico, n. 823,
15.X. 1968
) or with 3 setae ( 1 ♀ from Italy , Masarolis; 1 ♀ from Slovenia , Most na Soči;
2 ♂
, id.,
15 .IX. 2003
; 2 ♀ from Slovenia , between Godovič and Črni Vrh). Standard chaetotaxy of sternites
II–X 10
:( 3 ) 8–10 ( 3 ):( 2 ) 7–8 ( 2 ): 8 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 7 ; sternite II rarely with 9 or 11 setae, IV rarely with 9 setae and 1 stigmatal microseta; V rarely with 9 setae; genital opening of males flanked by 7–8 (rarely 6 or 9 ) setae on each side. Chelicera (
Figs 63 –64
, 71–72 , 78–79 , 84 ) 2.1–2.4 (usually 2.3 ) (♂) or 2.1–2.3 (usually 2.2 ) (♀) times as long as broad, palm with 6 setae and 1 microseta laterally ( 1–2 microsetae in ♀ from Slovenia , Jama Virsnica); fixed finger with 10–15 teeth (distal tooth and third from distal larger and sharp) and 2–4 proximal microtubercles; movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ), 7–12 teeth proximally reduced in size and 2–5 proximal tubercles; gl ratio 0.50–0.54 , rarely 0.55–0.57 ; spinneret usually prominent, rarely weakly prominent (
Fig. 63
) or absent (
Fig. 64
), in males, prominent and apically rounded in females (
Figs 71 –72
, 79 ,
84
); rallum with 11 blades; serrulae interior and exterior respectively with 13–15 and 15–17 blades. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process),
I 3
+ 3 marginal microsetae (rarely 4 + 2 or 4 + 4 marginal microsetae),
II 4
(rarely 5 ),
III 5
(rarely 6 ),
IV 6
(rarely 7 ); coxa II with 7–21 (usually 11–15 ) coxal spines, coxa III with 4–9 (usually 5–7 ) coxal spines; intercoxal tubercle bisetose (with one seta in ♂ from Slovenia , Mozelj). Pedipalp: femur 5.6–7.5 (♂) or 5.5–7.4 (♀) times as long as broad; chela (
Figs 65 –66
, 73–74 , 80–81 ,
85– 89
) 5.3–6.1 (♂) or 4.6–5.4 (♀) times as long as deep; hand of chela 1.8–2.2 (♂) or 1.6 –2.0 (♀) times as long as deep; fixed chelal finger with marked sigmoid curvature in lateral view, with 15–26 (♂) or 12–21 (♀) teeth with dental canals, usually with
1– 3
intercalary microdenticles in most interdental spaces, rarely without intercalary microdenticles in females; first tooth reduced, distad of it or halfway between et and it (rarely at level of it in females); 11–24 (♂) or 9–19 (♀) large, sharp, weakly reclined teeth increasing in size as far as halfway along the finger, then reduced in size towards the base; 1–5 (♂) or 1–3 (♀) small proximal teeth with rounded tips and dental canals; base of fixed finger with 0–5 microtubercles; fixed finger at level of it/est with 3 (rarely 2 or 4 ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm (distance between successive apices 0.034–0.055 mm ) in males, or with 2 (rarely 3 ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm (distance between successive apices 0.046–0.080 mm ) in females; tip of fixed finger with apical sensilla af
1
‾
2
, distal paraxial seta spatulate, enlarged in the middle and becoming sharper apically; movable finger strongly curved in lateral view and always shorter than fixed finger; dentition of movable finger highly variable, even among individuals of the same population (e.g.
Figs 80–81
), usually with 20–28 (♂) or 16–26 (♀) low, broad, reclined teeth increasingly reduced towards the finger base, reaching back nearly to sb , proximally followed, between sb and b , by 2–8 vestigial teeth revealed only by the presence of dental canals (♂ from Italy , Ovaro, shows the highest reduction in number of teeth on movable finger: 9 normal + 4 vestigial); distal half of movable finger usually with 11–15 low, broad, reclined teeth (
Figs 65 –66
,
80– 81
), rarely with 6–10 triangular, reclined teeth, wider than high ( Figs 80 ,
88– 89
); coupled sensilla pc usually halfway between st and sb , rarely closer to st than to sb ; tip of movable finger with apical sensilla am
1
‾
2
; trichobothria as illustrated (
Figs 65 –66
, 73–74 , 80–81 ,
85– 89
); eb/esb/ist placed in a straight line or with ist distad of the line eb/esb ; ratio of movable finger/hand 1.6–1.8 (♂) or 1.5–1.8 (♀); ratio of femur/movable finger 1.0– 1.2 (♂♀); ratio of femur/carapace 1.2–1.7 (♂♀).

Description of tritonymph. Integument weakly pigmented, hispid granulation less marked than in adults. Carapace 1.0– 1.05 times longer than broad, anterior margin without epistome, denticles as in adults; anterior eyes with convex lens, posterior ones reduced to eye-spots; chaetotaxy 4 : 6 : 4 : 2 : 2 ( 18 ), length of anteromedian and anterolateral macrosetae respectively 0.095 and 0.050 mm . Chaetotaxy of tergites as in adults. Chaetotaxy of sternites
II–X 5
:( 2 ) 8 ( 2 ):( 1 ) 7 ( 1 ): 7 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 7 . Chelicera 2.15 times as long as broad, palm with 5 setae and 1 microseta laterally; fixed finger with 10 teeth, the distal two larger, the following proximally reduced in size; movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ) and 10 teeth; gl ratio 0.56 ; spinneret prominent and apically rounded, as in females; rallum with 9 blades; serrula exterior with 13 blades. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process),
I 3
+ 2 marginal microsetae,
II 4
,
III 5
,
IV 5
; coxa II with 6–7 coxal spines, coxa III with 4 coxal spines; intercoxal tubercle bisetose. Pedipalp: femur 4.9–5.5 times as long as broad; chela 4.85–5.5 times as long as deep; hand 1.7 –2.0 times as long as deep; fixed finger with 11–13 reclined teeth with canals, with
1 intercalary
microdenticle in most interdental spaces; distal tooth reduced, at level of it , 1–2 proximal teeth low, with rounded tips; fixed finger at level of it/est with 4 teeth occupying 0.1 mm (distance between successive apices 0.027 mm ); distal paraxial seta as in adults; movable finger with 16 low, reclined teeth increasingly reduced towards the finger base, reaching back halfway between st and b ; ratio of movable finger/hand 1.65–1.7 ; ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 1.1 ; ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.2–1.3 .

Measurements (in mm). Body length 1.0– 1.2 . Carapace 0.32–0.38 × 0.32–0.36 . Chelicera 0.28–0.30 × 0.13–0.14 , movable finger length 0.15–0.16 . Pedipalp: femur 0.42–0.47 × 0.085–0.095 ; chela 0.64–0.68 × 0.12–0.14 ; hand length 0.22–0.24 ; fixed finger length (from tip to eb ) 0.42–0.43 ; movable finger length 0.37–0.38 .

Remarks.
Chthonius raridentatus
was described by
Hadži ( 1930 )
from three specimens from as many Slovenian localities: one paratype of unstated sex from a cave on Mt Krim, south of Ljubljana [cave Velika Pasica, n. 75, 700 m a.s.l., Zgornji Ig, Rakitna (T. Novak in litt.,
12 .V. 2013
)]; one paratype of unstated sex from the cave Boštonova jama near Domžale [= cave Boštonova jama, no. 757 , Krtina, Domžale (T. Novak in litt.,
12 .V. 2013
)]; and the female holotype—“mounted on a slide and used as the type ” (
Hadži 1930 , p. 134 , translated
)—from Frauenloch cave near Borovec, Kočevje [= cave Babja luknja pri Borovcu, no. 93, 650 m a.s.l., Borovec, Kočevje (T. Novak in litt.,
12 .V. 2013
)]. These specimens cannot be found in the Institute of Zoology at the Univ. Ljubljana, the Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts, or the Prirodoslovni muzej Slovenije in Ljubljana (T. Novak & T. Trilar in litt.,
4 .XII. 2012
). It is possible that they are in the collections of the Institute of Zoology of University of Belgrade, but a request for information from that institution went unanswered. Hadži’s ( 1930 ) description of
C. raridentatus
contains some contradictions concerning the sex of the type specimens: although males are not explicitly mentioned among the material examined, it is reported that the “male is a little smaller and thinner, while showing no obvious differences (except those in the genital apparatus) with respect to the female” (
Hadži 1930 , p. 140 , translated
); also, captions of figures 10–13 (p. 142 ) refer to a male, even if there are evident errors with reference to the respective drawings, notably fig. 11 , which clearly shows a female.
Hadži ( 1930 )
considered
C. raridentatus
to be related to
C. troglodytes Redikorzev, 1928
,
C. heterodactylus
and, in particular,
C. cavernarum
, and emphasized that the only difference between
C. raridentatus
and
C. cavernarum
lies in dentition of the movable chelal finger.

C. raridentatus
was redescribed by
Beier ( 1939 b
; repeated in
Beier 1963
) based on a female from the cave Boštonova jama ( Biospeologica balcanica no. 757 ) and compared to
C. subterraneus meuseli Beier, 1939
. Subsequent authors (see
Harvey 2013
) added solely faunistic data for
C. raridentatus
.

The redescription of
C. cavernarum
, based on a male from “Breznohöhle ober Bischoflak” (= cave Migutovo brezno no. 5 near Škofja Loka), Slovenia , allowed
Beier ( 1939 b)
to describe
Chthonius ellingseni
on specimens of both sexes from Austria (Annenheim am Ossiachersee and Villach), Slovenia (Mt Črna prst, near Bohinjska Bistrica), Montenegro (Herceg-Hovi) and, doubtfully, from Crete. These specimens were previously misidentified, apart from the one from Villach, as
C. cavernarum
( Beier 1928 , 1931 ,
1932
; see Remarks under
C. cavernarum
). The record from Crete (
Beier 1931
), based on material from the Roewer collection, is probably erroneous due to the mislabelling of material from the eastern Alps or Slovenia (
Helversen & Martens 1972
). Because of the uncertainty concerning the correct identification of syntypes from Montenegro and Crete, a lectotype female has been designated from Slovenia (Mt Črna prst, near Bohinjska Bistrica).
Ćurčić ( 1974 )
mistakenly reported the cave “Završka jama” as type locality of
C. ellingseni
.

Chthonius ellingseni
was subsequently redescribed by
Beier ( 1963 )
, incorporating some morphological characters from
Beier ( 1931 )
and others, including part of the measurements and the figure of the chela, from
Beier ( 1932 )
. According to
Beier ( 1963 )
, the main differences between
C. raridentatus
and
C. ellingseni
are found in the carapacal chaetotaxy (setae of basal row: 2 versus m 2m , respectively) and the dentition of the chelal fingers (fixed finger without intercalary microdenticles in
C. raridentatus
, versus fixed finger with intercalary microdenticles in
C. ellingseni
; fixed finger with 13 sharp teeth proximad of est , versus fixed finger with 19 sharp teeth proximad et ; movable finger with reduced dentition, versus movable finger with evident reclined teeth distad of sb ).

Chthonius brandmayri
was described by
Callaini ( 1986 )
, from one male and two females collected from Slavnik, Slovenian Istria, and compared with many species of
Chthonius ( Chthonius )
with a sigmoid fixed chelal finger from southeastern Europe and Anatolia , particularly
C. subterraneus meuseli
, but no comparison was made with
C. raridentatus
or
C. ellingseni .
The main characters proposed by Callaini ( 1991 ) to differentiate
C. brandmayri
from
C. s. meuseli
are the presence of 2 setae on tergite I ( 4 in
C. s. meuseli
) and the dentition of the distal half of the movable chelal finger (with reclined teeth, wider than high, in
C. brandmayri
; with erect teeth, higher than wide, in
C. s. meuseli
).

Chthonius jalzici
was described by
Ćurčić ( 1988 )
from a single female from the cave Veternica Špilja, near Zagreb, Croatia , and compared to
C. raridentatus
, from which it was stated to differ mainly in the number of setae in the posterior row of the carapace: 2 macrosetae and one microseta on each side in
C. jalzici
, 2 macrosetae in
C. raridentatus .
The holotype of
C. jalzici
is not deposited in the Hrvatski Narodni Zoološki Muzej in Zagreb, contrary to
Ćurčić ( 1988 )
(R. Ozimec in litt.,
10 .II. 2014
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 90. Distribution map for
Chthonius (C.) cavernarum
Ellingsen, 1909
(▲),
C.
(C.) heterodactylus
Tömösváry, 1882
(Δ),
C.
(C.) hungaricus
Mahnert, 1981
(■),
C.
(C.) lessiniensis
Schawaller, 1982
(□),
C.
(C.) pusillus
Beier, 1947
(●),
C.
(C.) raridentatus
Hadži, 1930
(○).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Examination of material from many Italian, Slovenian and Croatian localities, previously referred to
C. raridentatus
,
C. ellingseni
,
C. brandmayri
or
C. jalzici
(including types of
C. ellingseni
and
C. brandmayri
, and topotypes of
C. jalzici
), has revealed remarkable intra- and interpopulational variability in most of the characters used in previous comparisons of these species. This concerns in particular the carapacal and tergal chaetotaxy, the presence/absence of interdental microdenticles on the fixed chelal finger (
Figs 73–74
), the position of first distal tooth on the fixed chelal finger relative to trichobothria it–et (
Figs 73 –74
, 80–81 ,
86– 89
) and the dentition of the distal half of the movable chelal finger (
Figs 80–81
). The widest dimensional range was found in a sample from Most na Soči ( Slovenia ): length of pedipalpal chela 1.01–1.38 (♂) 1.02–1.64 (♀) mm, length of movable chelal finger 0.61–0.825 (♂) 0.62–0.94 (♀) mm (
Figs 65 –66
,
73– 74
). The following synonymies are therefore proposed:
Chthonius (C.) ellingseni Beier, 1939
,
C. (C.) brandmayri
Callaini, 1986
and
C. (C.) jalzici
Ćurčić, 1988
are all junior subjective synonyms of
C. raridentatus
Hadži, 1930
( n. syn. ).

Chthonius raridentatus
is a troglophilic species known from the eastern Venetian pre-Alps to southern Austria (Carinthia), Slovenia and northern Croatia (
Fig. 90
). Among the species of
Chthonius
of the
C. heterodactylus
group,
C. raridentatus
seems to be most closely related to the sympatric (rarely syntopic)
C. cavernarum
. Differences between
C. raridentatus
and
C. cavernarum
are given in the above key.
